analytic.title: Color Icons: Merging Color and Texture Perception for Integrated Visualization of Multiple Parameters

abstract.p: Multiparanreter data collection is becoming increasiirgly conamoti i n niatiy scietatific disciplines. The need exists for iiategrated displays to enable the scientist to see tRe coin.bitied ittforniation, some of which. may tgot be adequately perceived or may not be perceived at all tiheir rriewed individually. At, order for svch displays l o succeed. they must exploit th.e visual perceptual capabilities as much. as possible. W e present a ii.ew techtlique that harnesses color and texture perceptioia t o create iitdegrated displays of two-dinaensional 'imagelike " multiparanteter distributions. Tke power of th.e n e v~ tech.irique is denxoiastrated by an example of a syn-' t h s i t e d dataset conaparing it with several other proposed tecAtaiques. W e discuss the nature of studies required t o measure objectitrely and accurately the effechetaess of such displays.

div.head: Background
div.p: Multiparameter data collection is becoming increasingly coiiiiiioii in iiiany scientific disciplines. The data can be spatially coherent, such as medical images, satellitae iinages, or geological data for oil exploration; or it, can be iron-cohereat, such as population or census data. But it usually consists of a very large nuiiiber of soiiie higher diniensioaal vectors. The scientist is facc*d witall several images representing different, paranicters, each of which contributes to tlie process of analysis. Detection ancl classification of objects and pat terns ill tlie various iiriages require careful analysis uot only of tlie separate paraiiieters ill&\ idually, but also of relationships among corresponding regions across them. Scanning back and forth aiiiong the separate parameter images positioned side-by-side can he adequatqe only for the aiialysis of crude aspects of relationship; more subtle changes in tlie shape or iiitaeriial st>ructure of corresponding regioiis iiiay be very difficult to analyze. Moreover, in .soiiie cases, stxuctures of intered may not be visible clearly or at all in any one of tlie separate parameters. They niiglit , however, be visible in soiiie appropriately int<egrated display. The need exists for integrated displays to enable the scientist to see tlie combined information. In order for such displays to :jucceed, they must exploit the visual perceptual ~apabilit~ies as much as possible.

As iiiodern computer graphics aiid display teclinology provide a basis for iiiaiiy protilising ways to integrate multiparameter images, two visually-based techniques are becoining more and more recognized a 3 powerful nieaiis to achieve that. goal: 1. Color codirrg, which exploits humans' powerful color perception [9, 131; and 2. Geomefric coding, which employs shape and texture perception [g, 12, 131. A third approacli, s o i~z f i c a f i o~~ ([4]), wliicli lias showa t.rmieiidous pott.nt.iaI in coiijriiiction with visuallybased techniques. is beyoncl the scope of this article.

div.head: Potential Gains from Integration
div.p: We identify t.hree t,ypes of pot,ent,ial gains from int,egrat,ion [IO].
Type I: Chins in contrast. aiid conspicuousness of s t,ruc t. ures .
CH3046-0/91/oooo/o164~01.00 @ 1991 IEEE Type 11: Gains in the ability to classify structure types and in the ability to ass0ciat.e spatially disjunct regions of structwes of the same type.
Type 111: Gains from making structures that are not visible in any single parameter visible by conibining parameters.

div.head: Outline
div.p: This article discusses tlie development and evaluation of visually-based integration tecliniques that merge the perceptual powers of color and geometric coding techniques in general. In Section 2, we intmduce tlie notion of an zconographic display as a generalization of standard displays, and we describe briefly t,he two main approaches to visual integration, namely, color integration and geontetrtc integration, as iconographic displays. In Section 3, we present a new colorbased iconograpliic technique, which liarnesses color and texture perception to create integrated displays of multdparanieter distributions. The power of the new technique is denionstrated in Section 4 by an example of a synthesized dataset, comparing it with other proposed techniques. In Section 5 we discuss the nature of studies required t-o measure objectively and accurately the effect,iveness of such displays. Section 6 provides a discussion and direct>ions for future work.

div.head: Iconographic Integration Techniques
div.p: The iconographic approach provides a general structure for tlie specification and creation of integrated displays of "diparanieter images [9, 12, 131.

The basic primitive is the won, which is a generalization of a single pixel to higher dimensions having multiple perceivable features and attributes. It enables the representation of multiple values at each spatial location by controlling attributes of the icon's perceivable features.

Gray-scale pixels in images are the most degenerate form of an icon-a 1 x 1 patch with one attribute of variation, its intensity. Color coding of the 1 x 1 pixel patch provides the simplest extension, which is int roducing tjliree attributes of variation, its tristiiiiulus valries such as lightness, hue, and saturation. By expanding the area of the icon, albeit at potentially significant costs in spatial band-width, tlie icon acquires vistial features aiid attributes, such as shape and other aspects of geometry and color, all of which are datacontrollable. Stereoscopic depth and dynamic properties are other potential extensions.
We now describe briefly the two main approaches for visual int,egrat.ion; detailed descript(io1is can he found in the cited literature.

div.head: Color Integration
div.p: In color coding, each icon of the integrated representation is a color patch (txnditionally a 1 x 1 patchi.e., a pixel) whose tristiniulus values are controlled I)y the values of corresponding locations in (up to) t h e e input parameter distributions. Typically, tlie different parameters are niapped to the different coordinates of a color niodel [7]

div.head: Geometric Integration
div.p: Geoniet,ric coding, originally proposed by Picket t

[ 1 11, has been dei eloped at the University of Lowt.ll for visualization of large multiparametric databases and is rapidly gaining recognition as a powerful approach to integration, in particular wliere tlie nuniber of parameters exceeds three, which is tlie upper limit for color integration In this teclinique shape perception is utilized to senye local coinbinations of data, wliilr texture perception provicles a sense of glol)al spatial distribution of those It, caii be sho\i ii t,hat. sha.pe and color a.re perceptiially separable fea.tbures; t,liis iiieaiis t,liat, discrimina.t,ion of variations in t,liese two features are percept,ua.lly orthogonal. Lightness and size a.re a,lso sepa.rable. Separable features have t,lie hest pot,ent,ia.l as vehicles for successful coding of data, in part,icula,r for "unniixiiig" of parameters.

The color icon merges separable feat.ures by using color, slmpe, a.nd textmure percept*ion bo code mult,iple paraniet,ers iiit<o a single int,egrat,ed inia.ge. At. t,lie most, general Irvrl. thrcolor icon is n i l a w a o i l t.lw s c r w i . const,ruct,ed of one-dimensioiia.1 fea.tures (I,ountlaries and a.rea subc1iv:drrs). and t.c\.o-dimeiisioiia.l features (areas defined by t.he subdividers), ailcl {.heir at t,ril,rit,rs (orientat,ion, size, sha.pe, and color). Each of 1.liosr can be cont,rollec globa.lly (e.g., t.lie shape of (. is chosen to be rectangular for all icons), or can be mapped to be contmlled hy a dat.a parainet" ( e . g . , a subdivision point along a linear feat*ure is controlled by 3 parameter value).

div.head: A prototype implementation
div.p: We h v e iiiipleiiieiited a prot,ot,ype of a systeni to visualize data using the color icon. In this prototype, tlie ic,oii is ai1 111 x 71. rect.aiigle ( i n and n a,re globally under user control), see Figure 1. In one variant of the prot,otype, six linear feat,ures are used: two of t,lie edges (one horizoiit,al, one vert,ical), t8he two dia,goiials, mid the two iiiitlliiies. This provides coding of up t,o six paraiiieters (in a.dditioii to the (x, y) spat.ial loca.t,ioii). Tlie reiiia.iiiing t.wo edges are not used so as t.o ma.int.aiii bouiichry coiisisteiicy by avoiding coiiflicts with the lieigllboring spatial points. Those t,wo edges could, however, be used for t.wo additioiial pa.rameters. Tlie fea.tures subdivide the icon's area into several sulmreas. Tlie colors of those subareas a.re iiit,erpola.ted from the colors assigned to t,he linear fea.t,ures. In a.iiot,lier va.riant, t,he fea.tures used are t.he fields result.iiig froiii subtlivicliiig t.he icon's area. This yields a "pie clmrt," t,ype of an icon, wit,h eight. pa.ra,iiiet.er fields ( "slices" ). It seems t,liat t.he linear feat.ure a.pproa.ch provides bet,t,er blending of pa.raniet,er va.lues, while the area. feat,ure one provides bett,er sepa.ra.bi1it.y of pa.rameter values.

Ea,cli fea.t,ure is iiia.ppt?d to one da.ta. pa.raniet,er. 111 t,lie current, prot.ot,ype t,he att.ribut,e uiicler data corit,rol is the color of t8he featsure; the va.lue of tlie pa.ramet,er detenniiies all three color coordinates of the fea.ture2 via. a point,er t,o a color sca.le. Different paraiiieters may sliare the smie color scale or iiiay point to iiidividual color scales. Figure 2 shows t,he ma.ppings of paraiiiebers to linea,r fea.t,ures as t,lie iiumber of parameters vary from one t80 six.

A prot.otype syst,em lias heell iinplement,ed on a, variet.y of workst,at.ioiis in C', under X-windows using t,he OSF/Mot.if t,oolkit,. It supports sepamte display, a.iicl indivic1ua.l color sca.le a.ssigniiieiit,s for up to six pa,raniet,ers. A region-of-interest selectmion capabilit,y, which selects corresponding regioiis in all input. ima.ges, allows disphying ImrC of t,he iiiia.ge in tlie iiit,egrat,ed disp1a.y.

div.head: Other possibilities
div.p: The general definition of tlie color icon allows many variations:

0 The number of parameters to be coded can be tripled by liaviiig each parameter control oiily oiie color paraiiicter (such as the lightness, hue, or saturation) of a feature. In such a case, three pa-raiiiet>ers control the color of a feature, whereas in tlie current prototype, one parameter controls t#he color of the feature, coiiipare Figures 1 aiid 3. Different color iiiodels and different mappings of parameters to color coordinates provide atlditioiial diversity of displays.

0 More t,liaii one parameter can be mapped t,o a linear feature by subdividing its lengt(1i. Subdivision can be fixed globally (e.g., all linear feat,ures are subdivided in tlie middle) or can be data-controlled, where the point of subdivision is controlled by the value of a parameter.

0 Tlie contributions of different parameters to the colors of the icon can be weighted. Tliis can be achieved algebraically (by using a different interpolatioii functioii to compute the relat,ive contributions) or geoinetrically (by cliangiiig tlie location of int.ersect,ioii point,s, the contributions of different. paraiiiet,ers t,o the colors of t.he icoii are given different, weights). Tlie two approaches can be coinbiiied. Figure 5. These relationships becoiiie perceivable when integrated a,ppropria.tely, see Figures G-9. This illustmtes our conjecture tha.t, in soiiie cases intergrated disp1aj.s 1iia.y be the only effect,ive wa.y to inake some relat,ioiisliips in the da.ta perceivable.

div.head: Evaluation Studies
div.p: As we h v e clescril,ed and tleiiioiist.rated above, there a,re iiiany different, possibilities t,o generake iiitegra.t.ed disp1a.y. From a. tecliiiological point of view iiiost, of t81ieni are feasible. However, it. is not possible t.o det,ermiiie their efficacy without evaluation studies wit,li liuiiiaii observers.

Tlie first, step t.owards evaluateion is selecting a,iid a.cljust,iiig the various imaging variables so as to explore t.he different. coiiibiiia.t,ioiis that are possible. In such a. st,utly, imrticipants t.ry different, viewing va.ria.bles of t.he iiit*egra,ted iiiiagiiig system. Viewing variables iiiclude different, fea.t,ures, a,t.t.ributes of fea.t,ures, t.he shape a.iid size of t.lie icon (different, t,essella.t.ions), pa.ra.inet,er-t,of~at,ure mappings, and color scale selectioii a.iid assigiinieiit. Since the iiuiiiber of combiliat.ions ca.ii he very large, the goal is t>o ideiit,ify particular select.ions a.iitl va.lues t.1ia.t a.ppear to be most. prouiising. Those choices a.re t.lieii used for subsequent,, inore ela.borat,e st,utlies. Such st,utlies eiiiploy specific tasks siicli as detection, classification, localization, and quanlificatioii of objectas (e.g. detect the esistence of a target in a background, or sp'cify whet lirr tshere is a horizontal or a vertical split in the iniage); larger saiiiple sizes; larger numbers of participants; aiid more rigorous analysis iiiet hods.

When desigiiiiig such st uclies. hoth real images ant1 syiithesized data should he coiisitlerecl. Real rlat a present. real world prohieins hut iiiay lack informat-ioii about the "truth" (e.g., in iiiedical images, it is not always easy to know whether the image is normal or abiiorinal). The coiiteiit4s of synthesized data is always kiiowii, ancl can be adjusted to test situatioiis for which real data is not kiiowii to Iw available (for example, inter-aiid intra-image relationships like the ones deiiioiistratcd here inay iiot be perceived in real data). However, results from studies using syiithesizecl data iiiiglit not exteiid to the real world

div.p: We linve discussed t.he general iiot.ioii of iconographic i ii t,egra.t,ed dinp1a.y.s of iiiu 1 t,ipa,ra.iiie t.r i c cl a. t.a..
